Hi  Ron,


In the recent book of the Masamune exhibition on page twelve there is an 
oshigata of an Awataguchi Kunitsuna tachi which appears to show
a similar feature.


Charles.
On Wednesday, December 10, 2003, at 03:12 AM, Ron Hartmann wrote:

> Hi all -
>
> The latest Token Bijutsu journal (NBTHK) shows a wonderful tanto by 
> Awataguchi Yoshimitsu (late Kamakura), illustrated on the fold-out 
> page. The boshi of this tanto shows (as described), "...the boshi is 
> sugu then turns back in ko-maru with hakikake then nie-no-kui-sagari 
> (descending nie line)...) Personally, I've never noticed this odd 
> characteristic on any illustrated swords before although it seems 
> "somebody" recently asked me about this kind of thing.
>
> For those of you who do not have this journal, picture the boshi as 
> described and at the end of the rather extended kaeri, there is a short 
> "wisp" of nie that comes down off the end of the kaeri at about a 45 
> degree angle, into the ji. Interesting odd nie formation! Can anyone 
> elaborate on this characteristic, if it is unique to Yoshimitsu or 
> perhaps Awataguchi blades in general, whatever??? Comments?
>
> Ron
> STL
>
